etymologies: Middle English enherite ‘receive as a right’, from Old French enheriter, from late Latin inhereditare ‘appoint as heir’, from Latin in- ‘in’ + heres, hered- ‘heir’

definitions: receive (money, property, or a title) as an heir at the death of the previous holder

examples.text: she inherited a fortune from her father

shortDefinitions: receive property or title on someone's death

definitions: derive (a quality, characteristic, or predisposition) genetically from one's parents or ancestors

examples.text: she had inherited the beauty of her grandmother

shortDefinitions: derive characteristic from parents or ancestors

definitions: receive or be left with (a situation, object, etc.) from a predecessor or former owner

examples.text: spending commitments inherited from previous administrations

shortDefinitions: be left with something from predecessor

definitions: come into possession of (belongings) from someone else

examples.text: she inherits all her clothes from her older sisters

definitions: come into possession of (something) as a right (especially in biblical translations and allusions)

examples.text: master, what must I do to inherit eternal life?

shortDefinitions: come into possession of something as right
